awd_titl_txt: Collaborative Research: Long Term Sublimation/Preservation of Two Separate, Buried Glacier Ice Masses, Ong Valley, Southern Transantarctic Mountains
awd_abstract_narration:
Putkonen/1445205


This award supports the study of a large body of ice that is buried beneath approximately a meter of debris in the Ong Valley of the Transantarctic Mountains of East Antarctica. Preliminary analyses of this material suggest that it could be over a million years old.  Most glacial ice contains tiny air bubbles that have trapped the atmospheric gases and other atmospherically transported materials existing at the time that the ice was deposited such as plant pollen, microbes and mineral dust.  Samples will be collected from this buried ice mass, down to a depth of 10 meters, and cosmogenic nuclide concentrations both in the overlying debris and in the till contained in the ice will be measured. This site could contain some of the oldest ice on Earth and studies of the material contained within it may help researchers to better understand the processes involved in its survival for such long periods of time. This work will also help inform scientists about the processes involved in the development of landforms here on earth as well as those on Mars where similar dirt covered glaciers are found today.

Samples of the buried ice will be collected in Ong Valley and analyzed to determine the cosmogenic nuclide concentrations in both the overlying debris and in the mineral matter suspended in the ice. The combined analysis of the target cosmogenic nuclides (Beryllium-10, Aluminum-26, and Neon-21) will allow the age of the ice to be uniquely determined and will enable determination of the rate that the ice is sublimating. The intellectual merit of this research is to unequivocally determine the age of the ice and the sublimation rate of the ice in Ong Valley, Antarctica and to better understand if this an uniquely Antarctic process or whether it could exist elsewhere on earth or on other planets.  The work may also lead to the recognition of the oldest buried ice ever found on Earth and would provide a source from which direct information about the atmospheric chemistry, ancient life forms, and geology of that time could be measured.  The broader impacts of this work are that it will be relevant to researchers in a number of different fields including glaciology, paleoclimatology, planetary geology, and biology. Several students will also participate in the project, conducting Antarctic field work, making measurements in the lab, attending meetings, participating in outreach activities, and producing videos. A graduate student will also write a thesis on this research.  The results will be published in scientific journals and presented at conferences. The project requires field work in Antarctica.

por.por_cntn:
During their previous research expedition to Ong Valley, Antarctica, Dr. Putkonen along with his collaborators had discovered massive, glacier ice, below just three feet of dirt. The hidden glacier was located in a mountain valley and it was about a two-mile-long and a half-mile-wide. Clearly a large alpine glacier, but completely hidden from view under a thin layer of dirt. Their previous work had also shown that the dirt on top of the ice was over a million years old, but it was possible that the ice would be much older.

The reason they wanted to determine the exact age of the ice is that the ice contains all kinds of information about the environment and the atmosphere from the time the glacier originally formed. And very little is known about the climate in Antarctica beyond about million years ago, because most glaciers on Earth are just a few hundred or a few thousand years old. Even the bigger ones tend to be in the range of 50,000-800,000 years old. Therefore, if they could find ice that is older than one million years researchers could determine what the atmosphere in Antarctica was at that time, for example how much carbon dioxide was in the atmosphere.

They flew to Ong Valley and drilled into the ice and collected two separate 30 ft long ice cores. The research team that came from two Universities and one research institution worked with the two graduate students to analyze the dirt they found in the ice core. They determined that they had found two glaciers. A younger glacier on top of an older one. Moreover, the younger ice turned out to be 3 million years old, and the older one 4-5 million years old. These were some of the oldest glaciers that had ever been found on Earth. Based on this evidence it is clear that the Antarctic ice sheet has expanded twice, and repeatedly flowed into this small valley. This is providing the science a direct evidence of what the ice sheet was doing in the past. These results will give the researchers a better understanding on how the climate in Antarctica compared to the rest of the globe at those times, which in turn will help us all to better understand the global changes in the climate.

When Dr. Putkonen with his collaborators started this project only two buried glaciers were known in Antarctica, but since the Ong Valley location turned out to be scientifically so great, they wanted to see if there are other places where glacier ice may be still hiding. They studied over 8,000 satellite images and with the help of additional analyses they found 22 new valleys that are very likely to contain buried glaciers as well. Without visiting those places, it is impossible to tell for sure if the ice is there, and how old it might be. But these will be their next targets to continue to search for the oldest ice on Earth.
